greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Irregular triangle T(n,k), n>=1, 1<=k<=A186971(n), read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of k-element subsets of {1, 2, ..., n} containing n and having pairwise coprime elements.
comment: T(n,k) = 0 for k>A186971(n). The triangle contains all positive values of T.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..220, flattened
example: T(5,3) = 5 because there are 5 3-element subsets of {1,2,3,4,5} containing 5 and having pairwise coprime elements: {1,2,5}, {1,3,5}, {1,4,5}, {2,3,5}, {3,4,5}.
maple: s:= proc(m,r) option remember; mul(`if`(i<r, i, 1), i=factorset(m)) end:
a:= proc(n) option remember; `if`(n<4, n, pi(n)-nops(factorset(n))+2) end:
b:= proc(t,n,k) option remember; local c, d, h;
elif k=2 and t=n then `if`(n<2, 0, phi(n))
for h from 1 to n-1 by d do
if igcd(t, h)=1 then c:= c +b(s(t*h, h), h, k-1) fi
T:= proc(n,k) option remember; b(s(n,n),n,k) end:
mathematica: s[m_, r_] := s[m, r] = Product[If[i < r, i, 1], {i, FactorInteger[m][[All, 1]]}]; a[n_] := a[n] = If[n < 4, n, PrimePi[n] - Length[FactorInteger[n]]+2]; b[t_, n_, k_] := b[t, n, k] = Module[{c, d, h}, Which[k == 0 || k > n, 0, k == 1, 1, k == 2 && t == n, If[n < 2, 0, EulerPhi[n]], True, c = 0; d = 2-Mod[t, 2]; For[h = 1, h <= n-1, h = h+d, If[GCD[t, h] == 1, c = c+b[s[t*h, h], h, k-1]]]; c]]; t[n_, k_] := t[n, k] = b[s[n, n], n, k]; Table[Table[t[n, k], {k, 1, a[n]}], {n, 1, 20}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 17 2013, translated from Maple *)
xref: Rightmost elements of rows give A186994.
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 01 2011
